paper_title: Preparation of hierarchical g-C3N4@TiO2 hollow spheres for enhanced visible-light induced catalytic CO2 reduction

catalyst.source: Hierarchical g-C 3 N 4 TiO 2 hollow sphere with excellent photocatalytic activity for CO 2 reduction under the visible light was prepared by assembling TiO 2 shell onto the surface of hollow carbon nitride sphere (HCNS).
catalyst.context: Hierarchical g-C 3 N 4 TiO 2 hollow sphere with excellent photocatalytic activity for CO 2 reduction under the visible light was prepared by assembling TiO 2 shell onto the surface of hollow carbon nitride sphere (HCNS).This engineered photocatalyst was prepared by a two-step process: at first, the process of nanocasting was done by a templating method, followed by the kinetically-controlled coating technique.Specifically, mesoporous silica sphere and cyanamide were used as sacrificial template and precursor of carbon nitride, respectively, for the synthesis of hollow carbon nitride sphere which was further modified with titanium dioxide nanosheets.The remarkable photocatalytic activity of as-prepared nanocomposite could be attributed to its special structure, providing properties such as light-harvesting, multiple light reflection and enhanced active site.Owing to the synergistic effect between g-C 3 N 4 and TiO 2 ; the light absorption region has been enhanced, leading to the improvement of photocatalytic performance.The obtained CO 2 photoreduction efficiency of HCNSTiO 2 nanostructure is 11.3 mol/g cat .h,which is about 5 and 10 times higher than the corresponding values for pristine g-C 3 N 4 and p-25, respectively.

catalyst.source: Hierarchical HCNSTiO 2 hollow spheres were synthesized with the versatile kinetics-controlled coating method (Li et al., 2012).
catalyst.context: The mesoporous silica spheres as template were synthesized according to the Stober method (Buchel et al., 1988).Typically, 4.25 mL of aqueous ammonia (25) was added into a solution of 10 g of water and 58.5 g of ethanol at 30 C.After stirring for 30 min, 5.6 mL TEOS as a silica source was added while vigorous stirring, then mixture was held under stirring for 1 h to yield monodisperse silica sphere.To create a porous shell, a mixture of TEOS (5.2 mL) and C 18 TMOS (2.2 g) was prepared and added in a dropwise manner into the resulting solution with stirring and then kept in a static condition for 3 h to form a mesoporous layer around the silica cores.The as-prepared mSiO 2 /SiO 2 was centrifuged, dried at 80 C and calcined at 550 C with a rate of 5 C min -1 for 6 h.In order to enhance coordination to the carbon nitride precursor, the obtained spherical templates were neutralized through acidification with an HCl solution (1 M, 100 mL) at 60 C for 12 h and then washed with ethanol and dried at 70 C. The HCl-treated SiO 2 mSiO 2 (2 g) was mixed with cyanamide (10 g) under sonication and vacuum at 55 C for 2 h and after that, it was stirred at 60 C overnight.The obtained white powder was ground and calcined at 550 C with a rate of 5 C min -1 for 6 h.The resulting light-yellow solid was ground and treated in NH 4 HF 2 (1 M) for 10 h to remove the silica template, followed centrifuged and washed with water and ethanol for each one three times.The final yellow powder (HCNS) was dried at 70 C in a vacuum oven for 12 h (Zheng et al., 2015c). Hierarchical HCNSTiO 2 hollow spheres were synthesized with the versatile kinetics-controlled coating method (Li et al., 2012).The carbon nitride hollow spheres were dispersed by ultrasound in the mixture of absolute ethanol (100 mL) and concentrated ammonia solution (0.30 mL, 25 wt) for 20 min.Afterward, 0.75 mL of tetrabutylorthotitanate (TBOT) was added dropwise and the mixture was stirred at 45 C for 24 h.The resultant product was separated by centrifugation, followed by washing with ethanol and deionized water for 3 times, respectively, and was dried at 80 C overnight.Finally, the as made HCNSTiO 2 hollow spheres were heated at a ramp of 5 C and rested at 550 C for 4 h under Ar atmosphere. UV-Vis diffuse reflectance spectroscopy (DRS) was recorded on an Avant spectrophotometer (Avaspec-2048-TEC).Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) was performed by CM30 with an accelerating voltage of 200 kV.Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) micrographs was prepared with a MIRA3, TESCAN instrument equipped with energy dispersive X-ray (EDX) and elemental mapping.Powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) was carried out on a Philips diffractometer of X'pert company with mono chromatized Cu K radiation ( 1.5406A).N 2 and CO 2 physisorption was performed with a Micromeritics TriStar II plus at -196 C and 25 C respectively.Before measurements, the sample was degassed at 100 C for 12 h under vacuum.Thermal gravimetric analysis (TGA) was performed on STA BAHR 503 instrument in the temperature range from 25 to 900 C with heating rate 10 C min -1 under air atmosphere.The XPS signals were recorded using a Thermo Scientific K-Alpha XPS system (Thermo Fisher Scientific, UK) equipped with a microfocused, monochromatic Al K X-ray source (1486.6 eV).Photoluminescence (PL) spectra of samples were recorded at room temperature using an Agilent-G980A instrument.Gas chromatography (GC) analysis was performed using a Bruker SCION 456-GC instrument with a flame-ionization detector (FID).Photochemical reactions were carried out in a cylindrical glass reactor with a 300 W Xenon lamp (Lelesil innovative system, India), equipped with magnetic stirrer and chiller to control the temperature (15 C) during the experiments.

catalyst.llm generation: HCNSTiO 2 (a heterojunction photocatalyst formed from TiO 2 and g-C 3 N 4)
catalyst.source: In summary, engineered photocatalyst, HCNSTiO 2 , with a controllable structure was designed by combining the method of hard templating and kinetically-controlled coating.
catalyst.context: In summary, engineered photocatalyst, HCNSTiO 2 , with a controllable structure was designed by combining the method of hard templating and kinetically-controlled coating.The tailored photocatalyst with attractive properties showed a valuable performance for the CO 2 conversion to solar fuels under visible light irradiation.The heterojunction photocatalyst formed from TiO 2 and g-C 3 N 4 with a special hierarchical hollow structure showed a higher potential than each individual component in the photoreduction of CO 2 .Methanol was the main product in the first hour from the beginning of the reaction; consequently, the solar fuel (CH 3 OH/CH 4 ) can be obtained by the control of the photoreduction time of CO 2 .The as-prepared photocatalyst also exhibited excellent cycling photostability as well as chemical stability in reaction media.This study demonstrated that nanoengineered strategy can promote the photocatalytic activity and will open the new direction for development of promising nanostructures for advanced photochemical applications. Fig. 1.Overall flowchart for fabrication of HCNSTiO 2 architecture (steps I-III); corresponding FESEM (a-d) and TEM (e, f) images of the HCNSTiO 2 fabrication procedure. Fig. 2. XRD patterns of HCNS and HCNSTiO 2 samples. Fig. 3.The survey (a) and the corresponding high-resolution XPS spectra (b) C 1s, (c) N 1s, (d) O 1s and (e) Ti 2p of hierarchical HCNSTiO 2 photocatalyst. Fig. 4. The photoluminescence (PL) emission spectra of g-C 3 N 4 , HCNS and HCNSTiO 2 , ex 325 nm. Fig. 5. (a) Diffuse reflectance spectra, and (b) plot of (h) 2 versus photon energy for g-C 3 N 4 , HCNS, and HCNSTiO 2 photocatalyst. Fig. 6.TGA curves of HCNS and HCNSTiO 2 samples. Fig. 7. a) N 2 -adsorption/desorption isotherms of g-C 3 N 4 , HCNS and HCNSTiO 2 b) CO 2 adsorption isotherms of g-C 3 N 4 , HCNS and HCNSTiO 2 . Fig.9.Photocatalytic hydrocarbon production rates over HCNSTiO 2 after 1 h visible-light irradiation (The error bar represents one standard deviation). Fig. 10.Time-dependent photocatalytic reaction of CO 2 in presence of HCNSTiO 2 architecture (The error bar represents one standard deviation). reaction medium.source: The CO 2 photoreduction of as-prepared samples was carried out by CO 2 bubbling in aqueous solution under visible-light irradiation and atmospheric pressure.
reaction medium.context: Fig. 1 shows the overall fabrication procedure of HCNSTiO 2 and the corresponding FESEM, and TEM images of the nanostructures at each preparation step.At the first step, silica spheres as sacrificial template were coated with uniform g-C 3 N 4 layer through thermal polycondensation of cyanamide at 550 C (step i).In the second step, the SiO 2 cores were dissolved in the NH 4 HF 2 solution to obtain carbon nitride hollow spheres with monodisperse distribution (step ii).Finally, the as-prepared HCNS nanospheres were coated with nanosheets of TiO 2 through the kinetically-controlled coating method to achieve hierarchical HCNSTiO 2 hollow sphere nanostructure (step iii).Fig. 1(a)-(d) shows FESEM images of formation steps of HCNSTiO 2 structure with spherical morphologies.Fig. 1a andb show nanosphere silica templates before and after coating with g-C 3 N 4 .It can be seen in Fig. 2a that SiO 2 cores have spherical morphology and uniform size with a diameter of 250 nm.After thermal-induced polymerization of cyanamide around silica cores, the obtained SiO 2 g-C 3 N 4 showed a rough surface with an increasing diameter to about 320 nm (Fig. 1b).Therefore, the diameter of g-C 3 N 4 shell is calculated about 70 nm that is consistent with the TEM image (Fig. 1e).As shown in Fig. 1c and1d after removal of SiO 2 template, the hollow space and outer C 3 N 4 shell of HCNS can be clearly visualized from some cracked HCNS structures.Furthermore, the hollow interior of carbon nitride is further confirmed by TEM images and the size of the core cavity was calculated about 250 nm, which is about the size of SiO 2 nanosphere templates (Fig. 1e).As shown in Fig. 1d the spherical nanostructure is retained after modification HCNS with TiO 2 .In addition the EDX pattern and EDX mapping analysis of HCNSTiO 2 nanocomposite (Fig. S1) confirms the dispersion of Ti and O throughout the carbon nitride network.The TEM image shown in Fig. 1f demonstrates the core-shell structure of HCNSTiO 2 with hierarchical structure. The crystalline phases of HCNS and HCNSTiO 2 were determined by XRD analysis as shown in Fig. 2. It can be seen that HCNS show (1 0 0) and (2 0 0) characteristic peaks around 12.9and 27.4, respectively, corresponded to the in-plane ordering of tri-s-triazine motifs and the interlayer stacking of aromatic rings (Shiravnd et al., 2017).For nanocomposite of HCNSTiO 2 , in addition to those two early peaks related to carbon nitride, the other main peaks appeared at 2 25.3,37.9, 48.1, 54.0, 55.2, and 62.8can be well-matched with anatase phase of TiO 2 (JCPDS 21-1272) formed on the surface of spherical carbon nitride.The peaks position of HCNS remained unchanged in HCNSTiO 2 , which indicated that modification of sphere C 3 N 4 with TiO 2 shell did not destroy its crystalline structure.However, with the formation TiO 2 shell, a smooth decrease was observed in the diffraction peak intensity of HCNS.That should be due to reducing amount of g-C 3 N 4 in the composite and also it could be due to the peaks intensity of TiO 2 appearance stronger than that of g-C 3 N 4 (Crake et al., 2019;Zhou et al., 2014;Jiang et al., 2018b). XPS was utilized to analyze the oxidation state, the surface chemical composition and the interaction between TiO 2 with HCNS support in the prepared photocatalyst.The XPS survey spectrum (Fig. 3a) indicates that the photocatalyst surface is primarily composed of C, N, O and Ti elements.As shown in Fig. 3b the high resolution XPS spectrum of C 1s can be divided into two peaks centered at 284.8 and 288.4 eV that the first peak is can be attributed to CeC coordination of the surface adventitious carbon or the sp 2 -bonded carbon of CeN and the second peak is attributed to sp 2 -bonded carbon in the triazine rings of g-C 3 N 4 .It can be seen that the binding energy of NeCeN in the prepared photocatalyst shifts to the higher energy region in comparison to pristine g-C 3 N 4 .Fig. 3c shows that the high-resolution N 1s spectrum of photocatalyst can be deconvoluted into the three individual peaks with the binding energies of 401.25 eV, 399.98 eV, and 398.78 eV.The mean peak at 398.78 eV is attributed to sp 2 hybridized aromatic nitrogen (CNeC) and the other two peaks centered at 399.98 and 401.25 eV can be assigned to the tertiary nitrogen groups (Ne(C) 3 ) of the triazine skeleton and the free amino group (CeNeH), respectively.However, these three peaks have a shift toward higher energy binding compared with pristine g-C 3 N 4 .The polymerization of cyanamide was confirmed by determining the presence (N-(C) 3 ) group in N 1s spectra.The two peaks of O 1s located around 530.4 and 532.5 eV (Fig. 3d) are assigned to the oxygen atoms in TieO band and hydroxyl group of adsorbed water molecules on the surface of the sample, respectively.As shown in Fig. 3e, two distinct peaks around 458.2 and 463.9 eV with a slightly shift toward lower binding energies compared with TiO 2 powder are observed in Ti 2p spectra that correspond to Ti 2p 3/2 and Ti 2p 1/2 of Ti 4 in TiO 2 , respectively.The shift of Ti 2p to lower binding energy and up-shifts observed for C 1s and N 1s can be attributed to the chemical environment change resulting from the interaction between TiO 2 nanosheets and HCNS support.These interaction may lead to the efficient separation of electrons and holes, thereby resulting in improved photoactivity (Li et al., 2017;Sheng et al., 2019). To determine the rate of separation and trapping of photogenerated electron-hole pairs and studying the lifetime of charge carriers, photoluminescence (PL) emission of samples were recorded in the range 350-800 nm with excitation wavelength at 325 nm.For monitoring the fluorescence property, 3 mL of the dispersed of the prepared materials (0.03 g/L in distilled water) was poured into a quartz cuvette and the PL spectra were recorded at room temperature.As shown in Fig. 4, pristine g-C 3 N 4 and HCNS showed an emission peak with the same intensity at about 460 nm.On the other hand, it is clear that after the composite formation of HCNS and TiO 2 , the emission intensity for HCNSTiO 2 composite is decreased at the same emission position, due to the appropriate separation of electron-hole pairs in HCNSTiO 2 composite.These results suggest that hierarchical nanostructure of HCNSTiO 2 can be operated as an improved photocatalyst. Absorption light ability is another effective property of the photocatalytic efficiency.In this regard, the light absorption properties of pristine g-C 3 N 4 , HCNS and HCNSTiO 2 were carried out by diffuse reflectance spectrometry (DRS) in the UV-Vis region of the electromagnetic radiation.As shown in Fig. 5a, no significant difference is detected for pristine g-C 3 N 4 and HCNS within the visible light range, and for HCNSTiO 2 sample, the absorption capability in the visible region of the spectrum is suitable after coupling between g-C 3 N 4 and TiO 2 semiconductors.The optical band gaps of pristine g-C 3 N 4 , HCNS and HCNSTiO 2 were calculated as 2.69, 2.73 and 2.87, respectively, by a plot of (h) 2 versus energy (Fig. 5b).These results revealed that HCNSTiO 2 composite has a good band gap which leads to its enhanced visible light response and more effective photocatalytic activity toward CO 2 reduction. To determine the TiO 2 content in the engineered photocatalyst, thermogravimetric analysis was performed from room temperature to 900 C under air atmosphere at a heating rate of 10 C min -1 .As can be seen in Fig. 6, for the HCNS rapid weight loss is observed from about 680 C and complete weight loss due to decomposition of g-C 3 N 4 is occurred in the temperature region around 700-720 C.The HCNSTiO 2 nanostructure has a significant weight loss at about 650 C, which can be attributed to decomposition of g-C 3 N 4 in the heterojunction structure.The complete decomposition of HCNS indicates that the silica template was completely removed in the procedure of synthesis.The TiO 2 amount in the composite is estimated to be 20 by remaining weight of composite after heating the photocatalyst over 700 C. The photocatalytic activity depends greatly on adsorption properties of semiconductor including specific surface area and porosity.The N 2 adsorption-desorption isotherms of HCNS, HCNSTiO 2 and pristine C 3 N 4 are shown in Fig. 7a.Unlike pristine g-C 3 N 4 , the typical type IV isotherm with an H 1 hysteresis loop for HCNS and HCNSTiO 2 , illustrates that these compounds have uniform mesoporous structures with slit pore geometry.The textural properties of the compounds consist of specific surface area (S BET ), total pore volumes (V t ) and average pore sizes (D BJH ) are shown in the inset of Fig. 7a.The calculated specific surface area for HCNS is significantly higher than pristine C 3 N 4 .Besides, by forming a TiO 2 layer around the HCNS and wrapping the pores with TiO 2 particles, the surface areas and pore sizes of HCNSTiO 2 in comparison to pure HCNS were partly decreased.Due to the high specific surface area and mesoporous textural of HCNSTiO 2 , the photocatalytic potential of the nanocomposite can be remarkably extended.Because CO 2 adsorption is the first step for its subsequent photocatalytic reduction, the CO 2 adsorption isotherms of HCNS, HCNSTiO 2 and pristine C 3 N 4 carried out at ambient temperature (Fig. 7b).The CO 2 adsorption capacity for HCNS and HCNSTiO 2 is significantly higher than pristine g-C 3 N 4 according to N 2 adsorptiondesorption analysis.Nevertheless, for HCNS and HCNSTiO 2 samples, the results are different and HCNSTiO 2 shows the slightly higher adsorption capacity of CO 2 than HCNS.These results can be attributed to interaction between CO 2 molecules and TiO 2 particles and the production of further adsorption sites on catalyst (Jiang et al., 2018a). Hierarchical HCNSTiO 2 photocatalyst with rational properties such as hollow structure and increased active surface area is favorable in order to superior photocatalytic performance.The obtained photocatalyst was used to investigate CO 2 photoreduction under visible light illumination.As a comparison, we also studied the photocatalytic activity of commercial TiO 2 (P-25), g-C 3 N 4 and p-25/g-C 3 N 4 as a benchmark.The CO 2 photoreduction of as-prepared samples was carried out by CO 2 bubbling in aqueous solution under visible-light irradiation and atmospheric pressure.Control experiments showed that in the absence of either light irradiation or photocatalysts no hydrocarbon products were detected under same conditions, thus confirming that both are necessary for CO 2 reduction reactions. The rates of photocatalytic CH 3 OH production after 1 h, over the P-25, g-C 3 N 4 , p-25/g-C 3 N 4 and HCNSTiO 2 were shown in Fig. 8.As can be seen from this figure, P-25 and pristine g-C 3 N 4 show the lowest yield of CH 3 OH production because of the high rate of recombination of photogenerated charge carriers and poor visible light activity.Photocatalytic efficiency of p-25/g-C 3 N 4 is better than both individual semiconductors, which evidences a synergy between the g-C 3 N 4 and p-25 semiconductor components.However, the heterojunction photocatalyst of HCNSTiO 2 with nanoengineered structure greatly enhanced the CH 3 OH production rate (11.3 mol/gcat.h).This amount is over 10 and 5 times higher than the photocatalytic activity observed for P-25 and pristine g-C 3 N 4 , respectively.Key factor responsible for the enhancement in the photocatalytic efficiency of HCNSTiO 2 composite is the synergistic heterojunction formation between hollow carbon nitride sphere with TiO 2 which facilitates a fast electron transfer at the interface between HCNS and TiO 2 and enhances e --h pairs separation (Sridharan et al., 2013).The presence of synergy formed between HCNS and TiO 2 , is confirmed with the increase in its PL emission intensity.Furthermore, this increased efficiency is returned to the hollow structure of HCNS, which improves the light-harvesting in the visible range This apparent extension in visible light photocatalytic activity of HCNSTiO 2 composite toward CO 2 photoreduction can be assigned to the smart design of nanostructured photocatalyst.The shape-engineered HCNSTiO 2 with high specific surface area and shorter charge diffusion pathway, lead to the excellent photocatalytic performance owing to enhanced light-harvesting and appropriate charge transfer with long lifetime (Sun et al., 2012;Bhunia et al., 2015;Khan et al., 2019).Besides, well-developed heterostructure formed between HCNS and TiO 2 enhances the photocatalytic activity by improving the separation efficiency of charge carriers in CO 2 photoreduction process (Wei et al., 2017;Li et al., 2017).In order to further analysis on the photocatalytic process of hierarchical HCNSTiO 2 composite, the hydrocarbons production was studied under the same experimental conditions described above by HCNSTiO 2 photocatalyst.As can be seen in Fig. 9, after the light irradiation for 1 h, methanol and methane are the main products while the other byproducts of CO 2 photoreduction, including of HCHO and HCOOH were negligible as they were measured by the GC-FID analysis. Because of the much higher production rate of CH 3 OH and CH 4 , we analyze the photocatalytic evolution of CH 3 OH and CH 4 with different reaction times, as shown in Fig. 10.Initially, methanol is the main product of the photocatalytic reaction, but the amount of methane continuously increases over time and its yield after 3 h arrives as high as 12.7 mol/g cat., which is comparable to that of methanol amount in the first hour of reaction.However, the production of CH 3 OH and CH 4 gradually start and continuously increase over time so that after 6 h amounts of CH 3 OH and CH 4 reached 52.1 mol/g cat .and 21.3 mol/ g cat., respectively.These results further demonstrate that the synergistic effect between HCNS and TiO 2 plays a major role for the generation of electron-hole pairs and therefore the improved photoconversion activity that introduces the shape-engineered HCNSTiO 2 composite as a powerful photocatalyst for CH 3 OH or solar fuel (CH 3 OH/CH 4 ) production (Sridharan et al., 2013;Lu et al., 2017a).
